revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jean Blackwell Hutson | image = | caption = | birth_name = Jean Blackwell | birth_date = {{Birth date|1914|9|7}} | birth_place = [[Summerfield, Florida|Summerfield]], [[Florida]], United States | death_date = {{death date and age|1998|2|4|1914|9|4|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Harlem Hospital]], New York | alma_mater = [[Barnard]],
[[Columbia University]] School of Library Science | nationality = American | occupation = Librarian, curator, writer, archivist | spouse = [[Andy Razaf]] (1939–1947)
John Hutson (1950-1998) | children = Jean Francis (d. 1992) | parents = Paul O. Blackwell (farmer)
Sarah Myers Blackwell (elementary schoolteacher)}} '''Jean Blackwell Hutson''' (born '''Jean Blackwell'''; September 7, 1914 – February 4, 1998{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/07/arts/jean-hutson-schomburg-chief-dies-at-83.html|title=Jean Hutson, Schomburg Chief, Dies at 83|first=Dinitia|last=Smith|date=February 7, 1998|website=nytimes.com}}{{cite web|url=http://littleknownblacklibrarianfacts.blogspot.com/2015/02/jean-blackwell-hutson-1914-1998-culture.html|title=Little Known Black Librarian Facts: Jean Blackwell Hutson (1914-1998): Culture Keeper Extraordinaire|first=Book|last=Nerd|date=15 February 2015|website=littleknownblacklibrarianfacts.blogspot.com}}Librarian and Archivist of Black Culture: Jean Blackwell Hutson. (2018) ''Barnard Archives''. https://barnardarchives.wordpress.com/2018/05/25/librarian-and-archivist-of-black-culture-jean-blackwell-hutson/Gunn, A. (1994). "Hutson, Jean Blackwell." ''Black Women in America''. Vol. 1, Thousand Oaks, Calif.: Sage Publications, p. 603. {{cite journal|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/asa-news/article/jean-blackwell-hutson-19141998/C4047719B9D2313D9BA640C7749C8680|title=Jean Blackwell Hutson, 1914-1998|first=David L.|last=Easterbrook|date=|publisher=|journal=ASA News|volume=32|issue=2|pages=5–5|via=Cambridge Core|doi=10.1017/S0002021400016388}} was an [[African-American]] librarian, archivist, writer, curator, educator, and later chief of the [[Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture]].Gubert, B. (2006)."Hutson, Jean Blackwell." ''Encyclopedia of African-American Culture and History'', edited by Colin A. Palmer, 2nd ed., Vol. 3, Macmillan Reference USA, p. 1085.{{Cite web|url=https://www.jstor.org.gate.lib.buffalo.edu/stable/25548798?Search=yes&resultItemClick=true&searchText=jean&searchText=blackwell&search&seq=10#page_scan_tab_contents|title=Library Feminism and Library Women's History: Activism and Scholarship, Equity and Culture|last=Hildenbrand|first=Suzanne|date=|website=www.jstor.org.gate.lib.buffalo.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-03}} == Early life and education == Jean Blackwell Hutson was born in [[Summerfield, Florida|Sommerfield, Florida]] and moved to [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]] with her mother in 1918. She graduated valedictorian from [[Frederick Douglass High School (Baltimore, Maryland)|Frederic Douglass High Schoo]]l in 1929.   Jean continued her education at the [[University of Michigan–Flint|University of Michigan]], studying [[psychiatry]], and transferred to [[Barnard College]], where she graduated with an English degree, [[Bachelor of Arts]] in 1935. In 1936, Ms. Hutson received her Master's degree in [[Library science|Library Science]] from [[Columbia University]]. She also acquired her teaching certificate from [[Columbia University]] in 1941. Ms. Hutson was married twice, to [[Andy Razaf]] 1939-1947 and John Hutson 1952-1957. She had a daughter, Jean Frances Hutson. == Career == Through the social and cultural prejudices against people of color and women, common at the time, Jean Blackwell Hutson made great gains in her professional career. From 1936 to 1984, she worked at multiple branches of the [[New York Public Library]] system, with a brief period as a school librarian at [[Paul Laurence Dunbar High School (Baltimore, Maryland)|Paul Lawrence Dunbar High Schoo]]l in [[Baltimore|Baltimore, Maryland]]. Her most notable professional position was as curator and chief of the [[Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture]] during which time she developed the Schomburg Dictionary Catalog. The collection at the Schomburg Center grew under her guidance to become, "a major source for research on Black history and culture". With a personal invitation from [[Kwame Nkrumah]], Hutson was asked to assist in Ghana with the development and creation of the African Collection.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/asa-news/article/jean-blackwell-hutson-19141998/C4047719B9D2313D9BA640C7749C8680|title=Jean Blackwell Hutson, 1914-1998|last=Easterbrook|first=David L.|date=14 July 2016|website=Cambridge Core|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} She took the opportunity to move to Ghana and spent the years of 1964-1965 at the University at Ghana. Hutson retired in 1980 but still remained active. She was still actively involved in organizations such as Information Science in the 1980s. She served on the Task Force on Library and Information Services to Cultural Minorities of the National Commission on Libraries. During her retirement she wrote a chapter on the Schomburg Center in Black Bibliophiles and Collectors: Preservers of Black History. == Merits and Involvement == During Hutson's lifetime, she was involved in many different civic, social, professional and cultural organizations. She was a member of [[Delta Sigma Theta|Delta Sigma Theta Sorority]], the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People|NAACP]], [[American Library Association|the American Library Association,]] the African Studies Association and the [[National Urban League|Urban League]]. Throughout her lifetime she received numerous awards. In 1966, Hutson received the Annual Heritage Award of the [[Association for the Study of Negro Life and History]] and 1974 , she received Black Heroes Memorial Award for Outstanding Community Service Commemorating the Lives of Malcolm.{{Cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/history/historians-and-chronicles/historians-miscellaneous-biographies/jean-blackwell-hutson|title=Jean Blackwell Hutson facts, information, pictures {{!}} Encyclopedia.com articles about Jean Blackwell Hutson|website=www.encyclopedia.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-04}} Additional awards received are as follows: * Honorary Doctorate King Memorial College * 1980 The Professional Service Award, [[Black Caucus of the American Library Association|Black Librarians Caucus of the American Library Association]] * 1989 "I Dream A World Exhibit" * 1990 Honored by [[Barnard College]] * 1992 Honored by [[Columbia University]] * 1992-2007 Residency Program in her name at [[University at Buffalo|SUNY Buffalo]] * 1994 Jean Hutson General Research and Reference Division named in her honor at the [[Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture|Schomburg Center]] * 1996 Annual Heritage Award of the [[Association for the Study of Negro Life and History]] == Death == On February 4, 1998, Jean Blackwell Hutson died at [[NYC Health + Hospitals/Harlem|Harlem Hospital]] in New York City at age 83.{{cite magazine|title=Jean Blackwell Hutson, Ex-Chief of Schomburg Center, Dies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VMQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA17&lpg=PA17&dq=jean+blackwell+hutson|accessdate=9 November 2018|magazine=Jet|page=17|date=February 23, 1998|volume=93|issue=13}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hutson, Jean Blackwell}} [[Category:1914 births]] [[Category:1998 deaths]] [[Category:Barnard College alumni]] [[Category:Columbia University School of Library Service alumni]] [[Category:University of Michigan alumni]] [[Category:African-American librarians]] [[Category:American librarians]] [[Category:Female archivists]] [[Category:Archivists]]

{{Infobox film | name = La terrazza | image = La terrazza (1980 film)poster .jpg | image_size = | caption = French film poster | director = [[Ettore Scola]] | producer = [[Pio Angeletti]]
Adriano De Micheli | writer = [[Ettore Scola]]
[[Agenore Incrocci]]
[[Furio Scarpelli]] | narrator = | starring = [[Marcello Mastroianni]]
[[Vittorio Gassman]]
[[Ugo Tognazzi]] | music = [[Armando Trovajoli]] | cinematography = [[Pasqualino De Santis]] | editing = [[Raimondo Crociani]] | distributor = | released = 1980| | runtime = 155 Min in Italy | country = Italy | language = Italian | budget = }} '''''La terrazza''''' is a 1980 [[cinema of Italy|Italian]] [[drama film]] directed by [[Ettore Scola]].{{cite web |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/150119/La-Terrazza/details |title=NY Times: La terrazza |accessdate=2009-03-29|work=NY Times.com}} The all-star cast features the best of [[Italian Cinema]] of its era: [[Marcello Mastroianni]], [[Ugo Tognazzi]], [[Vittorio Gassman]], [[Jean-Louis Trintignant]], [[Serge Reggiani]], [[Stefano Satta Flores]], [[Stefania Sandrelli]], [[Carla Gravina]], [[Ombretta Colli]], [[Milena Vukotic]]. The film director [[Ettore Scola]] and the screen writer [[Agenore Incrocci]] make [[cameo appearance]]s. ==Synopsis== On a terrace in [[Rome]], a group of Italian communist politicians and intellectuals have a party. ==Cast== * [[Vittorio Gassman]] - Mario * [[Ugo Tognazzi]] - Amedeo * [[Jean-Louis Trintignant]] - Enrico D'Orsi (as Jean Louis Trintignant) * [[Marie Trintignant]] - Isabella * [[Marcello Mastroianni]] - Luigi * [[Stefania Sandrelli]] - Giovanna * [[Carla Gravina]] - Carla * [[Ombretta Colli]] - Enza * [[Galeazzo Benti]] - Galeazzo * [[Milena Vukotic]] - Emanuela * [[Stefano Satta Flores]] - Tizzo * [[Serge Reggiani]] - Sergio * [[Agenore Incrocci]] - Vittorio (as Age) * [[Leonardo Benvenuti]] - A guest * [[Ugo Gregoretti]] - Another guest * [[Lucio Lombardo Radice]] - Himself ==Awards== *2 awards at the [[1980 Cannes Film Festival]]: [[Best Screenplay Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Screenplay]], Best Supporting Actress (Carla Gravina){{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/1848/year/1980.html |title=Festival de Cannes: La terrazza |accessdate=2009-05-27|work=festival-cannes.com}} *2 [[Nastro d'Argento]] awards: Best Screenplay, Best Supporting Actress (Stefania Sandrelli) ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{imdb title|0081616}} {{Ettore Scola}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Terrazza, La}} [[Category:1980 films]] [[Category:Italian films]] [[Category:Italian-language films]] [[Category:1980s drama films]] [[Category:Films directed by Ettore Scola]] [[Category:Films set in Italy]] [[Category:Self-reflexive films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Age & Scarpelli]] {{1980s-drama-film-stub}} {{1980s-Italy-film-stub}}

This is a '''list of [[Jewish Babylonian Aramaic]] and [[Jewish Palestinian Aramaic]] acronyms'''.
This list is far from complete; you can help by expanding it.
==Sorting order==
The entries in each section are sorted according to the Hebrew alphabet. Prefixes indicating prepositions and articles (such as ב, ד, ה, ש, כ) have been removed, with the following exceptions: *Where the acronym is incomprehensible or meaningless without the prefix *Where the prefix is so integral to the acronym that variants without it rarely, if ever, occur
==Numeronyms==
Some abbreviations included here are actually [[gematria]] ([[Hebrew]] [[numeronyms]]), but the number is so closely associated with some noun that it is grammatically used as a noun and is synonymous with it, for example ב"ן, Ban. Other abbreviations contain a variable gematria component alongside other words, like the chapter references פי"א perek yud-alef (chapter 11) or פ"ט perek tet (chapter 9). Rather than list separate entries for every possible gematria, or use only one number for an example, the gematria component is replaced with [x] to produce (for example) [x]"פ.
==Hebrew acronyms==
Some Hebrew acronyms are not included here; they may be found in the [[List of Hebrew acronyms]].
Many of the abbreviations here are similar or identical to corresponding Hebrew acronyms. In fact, a work written in [[Aramaic]] may have Hebrew acronyms interspersed throughout (ex. [[Talmud]], [[Midrash]]), much as a Hebrew work may borrow from Aramaic (ex. [[Tanya]]).
==List==
===א=== *איו אומרים, א"א ('''ein omrim''') - we cannot say *אריך אנפין, א"א ('''[[Arich_Anpin]]''') - The Partzuf of Hochma, the central, initial Partzuf in the world of Atzilut, from which all the other Partzufim originate. There is a special Partzuf, a system called Arich Anpin. Through it, the Light trickles downward and descends on us in droplets. We are unable to perceive the Light as a direct flow, but only drop by drop. *אצילות בריאה יצירה עשיה, אבי"ע ('''Abiya''', [[Atzilut]], [[Beri'ah|Beriah]], [[Yetzirah]], [[Asiah]]) - ([[Kabbalah]]) the [[Four Worlds]]. See בי"ע *'אפילו, אפי ('''afilu''') - even, even if *'אצילות, אצי ('''[[Atzilut]]''') - ([[Kabbalah]]) the highest of the [[Four Worlds]]. See אבי"ע *אדם קדמון, א"ק ('''Ak''', [[Adam Kadmon]]) - ([[Kabbalah]]) Primordial Man, a spiritual level transcending [[Atzilut]] *אמר רבי, א"ר ('''amar rabi''') - rabbi said *אמרו רז"ל, ארז"ל ('''amru razal''') - the sages said. See also רז"ל
===ב=== *בבא בתרא, ב"ב ('''[[Bava Batra]]''') - a tractate of the [[Talmud]], lit. final gate *בית דין, ב"ד ('''[[beit din]]''') - Jewish court of three adult men, lit. house of judgement. See also בי"ד *בית הלל, ב"ה ('''[[House of Hillel|Beit Hillel]]''') - the academy of [[Hillel the Elder|Hillel]], lit. the house of Hillel *בית דין, בי"ד ('''[[beit din]]''') - Jewish court of three adult men, lit. house of judgement. See also ב"ד *בריאה יצירה עשיה, בי"ע ('''Biya''', [[Beri'ah|Beriah]], [[Yetzirah]], [[Asiah]]) - ([[Kabbalah]]) the three nethermost of the [[Four Worlds]], where the denizens thereof are aware of their own existence. See אבי"ע *בבא מציעא, ב"מ ('''[[Bava Metzia]]''') - a tractate of the [[Talmud]], lit. middle gate *ב"ן ('''Ban''') - ([[Kabbalah]]) a spelling-out of the [[Tetragrammaton]] numerically equal to 52, the [[gematria]] of ב"ן. (Usually appears as שם ב"ן) *בסיעטא דשמיא, ב"סד ('''besiyata dishmaya''') - with the help of Heaven. Typically at the top right corner of a printed or written page. See also ב"ה in the [[List of Hebrew acronyms]] *בבא קמא, ב"ק ('''[[Bava Kama]]''') - a tractate of the [[Talmud]], lit. first gate *בית שמאי, ב"ש ('''[[House of Shammai|Beit Shammai]]''') - the academy of [[Shammai]], lit. the house of Shammai
===ג=== *'גומר(ה), גו ('''gomra/gomer''') - etcetera *גם כן, ג"כ ('''gam kein''') - as well, lit. like so also *'גמרא, גמ ('''[[Gemara]]''') - the explanation and discussion of the [[Mishna]] as printed in the [[Talmud]]
===ד=== *דאם כן, דא"כ ('''de'im kein''') - because if so
===ה=== *הרי הוא, ה"ה ('''harei hu''') - it is, he is *'הוי ('''Havayeh''') - ([[Kabbalah]]) "God," (a rearrangement of the letters indicating) the [[Tetragrammaton]], indicating kindness, mercy and revelation *הרי זה, ה"ז ('''harei zeh''') - this is *הוה ליה למימר, הול"ל ('''havah leih lemeimar''') - shouldn't he have said *הני מילי, ה"מ ('''hanei milei''') - this statement, lit. these words
===ח=== *חס ושלום, ח"ו ('''[[chas veshalom]]''') - Heaven forbid, lit. compassion and peace
===ט=== *טלית גדול, ט"ג ('''talit gadol''') - the large [[talit]]
===י=== *יצר הטוב, יצה"ט ('''[[Yetzer tov|yetzer hatov]]''') - the good inclination. See also יצ"ט *יצר הרע, יצה"ר ('''[[yetzer hara]]''') - the evil inclination *יצר טוב, יצ"ט ('''yetzer tov''') - good inclination. See also יצה"ט
===כ=== *כי אם, כ"א ('''ki im''') - unless *'כולו, כו ('''chulu''')- etcetera *כל שכן, כ"ש ('''kol shekein''') - all the more so. See also ק"ו
===ל=== *'לשון, ל ('''lashon''') - relating to, lit. tongue/language (used to indicate [[etymology]] or a definition)
===מ=== *מיין דכורין, מ"ד ('''mad/mayin dechurin''') - ([[Kabbalah]]) "masculine" waters, i.e. Heavenly action *מ"ה ('''Mah''') - ([[Kabbalah]]) a spelling-out of the [[Tetragrammaton]] numerically equal to 45, the [[gematria]] of מ"ה. (Usually appears as שם מ"ה) *מהדורא קמא, מהדו"ק ('''mahadura kama''') - "first edition," [[editio princeps]] *מכל מקום, מ"מ ('''mikol makom''') - in any case, lit. from any place *ממלא כל עלמין, ממכ"ע ('''memaleh kol almin''') - ([[Kabbalah]]) immanent in creation, lit. filling all [[Four Worlds|worlds]]. See also סוכ"ע *מיין נוקבין, מ"ן ('''man/mayin nukvin''') - ([[Kabbalah]]) "feminine" waters, i.e. human action *מצו(ו)ת עשה, מ"ע ('''mitzvot/mitzvat asei''') - positive commandment, lit. commandment [to] do. See also רמ"ח
===נ=== *נביאים וכתובים, נ"ך ('''Nach''') - the parts of the [[Tanakh]] aside from the [[Pentateuch]], lit. "Prophets and Writings." See also תנ"ך *'נוקבא, נוק ('''nukva''')- female, feminine *'נקרא, נק ('''nikra''') - it/he is called
===ס=== *סובב כל עלמין, סוכ"ע ('''sovev kol almin''') - ([[Kabbalah]]) transcending all creation, lit. surrounding all the [[Four Worlds|worlds]]. See also ממכ"ע *סטרא אחרא, סט"א ('''sitra achra''') - ([[Kabbalah]]) the side of unholiness and the [[Kelipot]], lit. the other side *סוף סוף, סו"ס ('''sof sof''') - ultimately, lit. end of end *ספר תורה, ס"ת ('''Seifer Torah''') - a [[Sefer Torah|Torah scroll]], containing the [[Torah]]
===ע=== *על זה, ע"ז ('''al zeh''') - on this, regarding this, above this *על ידי, ע"י ('''al yedei''') - because of, through agency of, lit. by the hand of *עד כאן, ע"כ ('''ad kan''') - until this point, lit. until here *על כך, ע"כ ('''al kach''') - thus, lit. [based] on this *על כן, ע"כ ('''al kein''') - therefore *על כרחך, ע"כ ('''al karchach''') - we are forced [to conclude], perforce, lit. on your compulsion *'עמוד, עמ ('''amud''') - side, page, lit. column *על פי, ע"פ ('''al pi''') - according to, lit. by the mouth of *עשרת ימי תשובה, עשי"ת ('''Aseret Yemei Teshuvah''') - the [[Ten Days of Repentance|Ten Days of Teshuvah]]
===פ=== *[x] 'פ ,[x] פרק ('''perek [x]''') - chapter [x]. But, see פ"ק *'פרשת, פ ('''parshat''') - the [Torah] portion of *'פירוש, פי ('''pirush''') - which means, lit. [the] explanation [is] *פסיק רישא, פס"ר ('''pesik reisha''') - obvious conclusion, lit. [if] the head is separated, [is it not dead?] *פרק קמא, פ"ק ('''perek kama''') - in the first chapter. See [x] 'פ *פירוש רש"י, פרש"י ('''pirush Rashi''') - [[Rashi]] explains, Rashi's explanation
===צ=== *צריך להיות, צ"ל ('''tzarich lihiyot''') - it should/must be (can be used to indicate a textual correction) *צריך עיון, צ"ע ('''tzarich iyun''') - [this] requires investigation. See also צע"ק *צריך עיון קצת, צע"ק ('''tzarich iyun ketzat''') - [this] requires a little investigation. See also צ"ע
===ק=== *קל וחומר, ק"ו ('''kal vachomer''') - all the more so, at least as much so, lit. light and weighty. See also כ"ש *קודשא בריך הוא, קוב"ה ('''Kudsha Brich Hu''') - the Blessed Holy One *קימלא לן, קי"ל ('''kaimla lan''') - we have established, lit. established for us *קריאת שמע, ק"ש ('''keriat shema''') - reading of the [[Shema]]
===ר=== *'ראיה, ראי ('''raya''') - proof *ראש השנה, ר"ה ('''[[Rosh HaShanah]]''') - the beginning of the year *רבותינו זכרונם לברכה, רז"ל ('''Razal''') - "Our Rabbis, of blessed memory," referring to Jewish sages of previous generations. See also חז"ל *ראש חודש, ר"ח ('''[[Rosh Chodesh]]''') - the beginning of the month *רחמנא לצלן, ר"ל ('''Rachamana litzlan''') - Heaven forbid, lit. may the Merciful One spare us *רעיא מהימנא, ר"מ ('''Ra'aya Mehemna''') - a commentary on the [[Zohar]], lit. The Faithful Shepherd *רמ"ח ('''remach''') - 248, indicating either the 248 positive [[mitzvot]] or the 248 organs of the human body. See also תרי"ג and שס"ה *רפ"ח ('''rapach''') - ([[Kabbalah]]) 288, indicating the 288 sparks resulting from the [[#Tohu-Chaos and the Shevirah-Shattering of the sephirot vessels|Shattering of the Vessels]] of the world of Tohu
===ש=== *'שנאמר, שנא ('''shene'emar''') - as it says *שס"ה ('''shesah''') - 365, indicating either the 365 negative [[mitzvot]], the 365 veins and sinews of the human body, or the 365 days of the solar [[year]]. See also תרי"ג and רמ"ח *שמנה עשרה, ש"ע ('''[[Shemoneh Esrei]]''') - (Liturgy) the amidah, or standing prayer, lit. [the order of] 18 [blessings] *שליח ציבור, ש"ץ ('''shali'ach tzibur''') - prayer leader, lit. emissary of the community *שבת קודש, ש"ק ('''Shabat Kodesh''') - the Holy [[Shabbat]] *שקלא וטריא, שקו"ט ('''shakla vetarya''') - ([[Talmud]]) discussion, give and take, lit. take and give
===ת=== *תורה שבכתב, תושב"כ ('''Torah SheBichtav''') - the [[Written Torah]]. See also תושבע"פ and תנ"ח *תורה שבעל פה, תושבע"פ ('''Torah SheBe'al Peh''') the [[Oral Torah]]. See also תושב"כ *תשבי יתרץ קושיות ואביות, תיק"ו ('''teiku''', Tishbi yetareitz kushiyot ve'avayot) - it stands unresolved, lit. the [[Tishbite]] ([[Elijah the Prophet]], in the time of the [[Moshiach]]) will answer questions and problems *תורה נביאים וכתובים, תנ"ך ('''[[Tanakh]]''') - the Bible, lit. "Torah [five books of Moses], Prophets and Writings." See also נ"ך *תנא קמא, ת"ק ('''Tanna kama''') - the first [[Tannaim|Tanna]] [mentioned] *תרי"ג ('''taryag''') - 613, usu. indicating the 613 [[mitzvot]]. Also used to indicate the 613 corresponding organs and veins of the human body. See also רמ"ח and שס"ה *תקיעה תרועה תקיעה, תר"ת ('''tarat''', tekiah teruah, tekiah) - a series of [[shofar]] blasts *תקיעה שברים-תרועה תקיעה, תשר"ת ('''tashrat''', tekiah, shevarim-teruah, tekiah) - a series of [[shofar]] blasts *תקיעה שברים תקיעה, תש"ת ('''tashat''', tekiah, shevarim, tekiah) - a series of [[shofar]] blasts *תפילה של יד, תש"י ('''tefilah shel yad''') - the arm [[tefillin]] *תפילה של ראש, תש"ר ('''tefilah shel rosh''') - the head [[tefilin]]
[[Category:Aramaic languages|+]]
[[Category:Lists of acronyms|Aramaic]] [[Category:Aramaic words and phrases| ]]

[[File:NYC - Guggenheim Museum.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in New York City was the first Guggenheim Museum established.]] [[File:Bilbao - Guggenheim aurore.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Guggenheim Museum Bilbao]] in Bilbao, Spain.]] The '''Guggenheim Museums''' are a group of museums in different parts of the world established (or proposed to be established) by the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation]].
Museums in this group include:
==Americas== * The [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in New York, New York, United States (1959–present)<ref name="artdaily">[http://www.artdaily.com/index.asp?int_sec=11&int_new=31711&int_modo=2 "Exhibition of Works Reflecting the Evolution of the Guggenheim's Collection Opens in Bilbao"], artdaily.org, 2009, accessed April 18, 2012</ref> ** The [[Guggenheim Museum SoHo]], a branch of the Guggenheim Museum located in Manhattan's [[SoHo]] neighborhood (1992–2001)<ref>Vail, Karole (ed) (2009). ''The Museum of Non-Objective Painting''. New York: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, pp. 25 and 36</ref> * The [[Guggenheim Guadalajara]] in [[Guadalajara]], Mexico (2007–2009)<ref>Kaufman, Jason Edward. [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Why-the-Guggenheim-wont-open-a-branch-in-Guadalajara-/8576 "Why the Guggenheim won’t open a branch in Guadalajara"], ''The Art Newspaper'', Museums, Issue 192, June 1, 2008; {{cite news |title=Cancela proyecto la fundación Solomon R. Guggenheim en Guadalajara |url=http://www.informador.com.mx/cultura/2009/149027/6/cancela-proyecto-la-fundacion-solomon-r-guggenheim-en-guadalajara.htm |newspaper=El Informador |location=Guadalajara, Mexico |date=26 October 2009 |accessdate= |trans-title=Solomon R. Guggenheim foundation cancels project}}</ref> * The [[Guggenheim Hermitage Museum]] in [[Las Vegas]], Nevada, United States (2001–2008)<ref> [http://www.guggenheimlasvegas.org/building_herm.html Guggenheim Hermitage Museum — The Building] from guggenheimlasvegas.org {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070824153552/http://www.guggenheimlasvegas.org/building_herm.html |date=August 24, 2007 }}</ref><ref>Peterson, Kristen. [http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2008/apr/10/vegas-say-goodbye-guggenheim/ "Vegas, Say Goodbye to Guggenheim"], ''[[Las Vegas Sun]]'', April 10, 2008, accessed on March 14, 2012</ref>
==Europe== * The [[Guggenheim Museum Bilbao]] in [[Bilbao]], Spain (1997–present)<ref name="artdaily"/> * The [[Peggy Guggenheim Collection]] in [[Venice]], Italy – originally the private collection of Peggy Guggenheim (1951–present)<ref name=Priceless>Walsh, John. [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/the-priceless-peggy-guggenheim-1806124.html "The Priceless Peggy Guggenheim"], ''The Independent'', October 21, 2009, accessed March 12, 2012</ref> * The [[Deutsche Guggenheim]] in [[Berlin]], Germany (funded by Deutsche Bank; 1997–2013)<ref>{{Citation| title = Frommer's Europe|author1=Darwin Porter |author2=Danforth Prince |author3=George McDonald |author4=''et. al'' |publisher=John Wiley and Sons| year=2006| isbn= 978-0-471-92265-0|page=339| accessdate = 2009-10-01| url =https://books.google.com/books?id=5hdsVl8cBgwC&pg=PA399&dq=%22Deutsche+Guggenheim%22&q=%22Deutsche%20Guggenheim%22}}</ref><ref name=SpiegelClosing>Kuhla, Karoline. [http://www.spiegel.de/international/zeitgeist/final-exhibition-guggenheim-says-goodbye-to-berlin-a-867541.html "Final Exhibition: The Guggenheim's Farewell to Berlin"], ''Spiegel Online'', November 15, 2012</ref> * The [[Vilnius Guggenheim Hermitage Museum]] in [[Vilnius]], Lithuania (proposed 2008; abandoned 2010)<ref name="lithuaniatribune.com">"[https://web.archive.org/web/20120203025213/http://www.lithuaniatribune.com/2011/02/07/guggenheim-museum-initiative-in-vilnius-to-be-taken-over-by-the-finns/ Guggenheim Museum initiative in Vilnius to be taken over by the Finns], ''The Lithuania Tribune'' (February 7, 2011)</ref> * The [[Guggenheim Helsinki Plan]] for a museum to be constructed in [[Helsinki]], Finland (proposed 2011; abandoned 2016)<ref name=Gulstad>Gulstad, Hanne Cecilie. [http://theartnewspaper.com/articles/Guggenheim-director-back-in-Helsinki-to-revive-plans-for-a-museum/30187 "Guggenheim director back in Helsinki to revive plans for a museum"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131106023252/http://theartnewspaper.com/articles/Guggenheim-director-back-in-Helsinki-to-revive-plans-for-a-museum/30187 |date=2013-11-06 }}, ''[[The Art Newspaper]]'', August 8, 2013, accessed September 14, 2015</ref><ref name=Helsinki>Siegal, Nina. [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/30/arts/design/guggenheim-helsinki-museum-plans-are-rejected.html?_r=0 "Guggenheim Helsinki Museum Plans Are Rejected"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 30, 2016. accessed December 1, 2016</ref>
==Middle East== * The [[Guggenheim Abu Dhabi]], a planned museum in the [[United Arab Emirates]] (under construction)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/07/08/ap/entertainment/mainD8IO10580.shtml |title=Guggenheim to Build Museum in Abu Dhabi |last=Krane |first=Jim |date=July 8, 2006 |publisher=CBS News |accessdate=2008-09-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080526015521/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/07/08/ap/entertainment/mainD8IO10580.shtml |archivedate=May 26, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Guggenheim family]] * [[Guggenheim (disambiguation)]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation]] [[Category:Lists of museums|Guggenheim Museums]]

revision.comment: /* Art Journals */ italics (why so many in-text outside links on this page?)
revision.text:
This is a list of out-of-copyright '''books and journals about [[art]] and [[artist]]s''', available online to read or download. Includes the visual arts, such as painting, engraving, sculpture etc., only.
==Encyclopedias of artists==
*'''''Biographical dictionary of medallists: coin, gem, and seal engravers, mint-masters, etc.''''' by [[Leonard Forrer]] (London: Spink & son, 1904): : Volume 1 (A-D) (missing) :[https://archive.org/details/biographicaldict02forriala Volume 2 (E-H)] :[https://archive.org/details/biographicaldict03forriala Volume 3 (I-Maz)] :[https://archive.org/details/biographicaldict04forriala Volume 4 (M.B.-Q)] :[https://archive.org/details/biographicaldict05forriala Volume 5 (R-S)] :[https://archive.org/details/biographicaldict06forriala Volume 6 (T-Z)]. :[http://quod.lib.umich.edu/g/genpub/ajk5386.0007.001?view=toc Volume 7 = Supplement]
*'''''Bryan's dictionary of painters and engravers''''' (New York: Macmillan, 1903). Illustrated: :[https://archive.org/details/bryansdiction01brya Volume 1 (A to C)] :[https://archive.org/details/bryansdiction02brya Volume 2 (D to G)] :[https://archive.org/details/bryansdiction03brya Volume 3 (H to M)] :[https://archive.org/details/bryansdiction04brya Volume 4 (N to R)] :[https://archive.org/details/bryansdiction05brya Volume 5 (S to Z)]
*'''''[[Dictionary of National Biography]]'''''' (Smith, Elder & Co., 1885–1901). Comprehensive biographical resource including British and Irish artists up to the year 1900 or so. *'''''Cyclopedia of painters and paintings''''', by J. D. Champlin & C. C. Perkins (New York: C. Scribner's sons, 1913). Illustrated with b/w drawings of art, artists and their monograms: :[https://archive.org/details/cyclopediaofpain01cham Volume 1 (Aagaard to Dyer)] :[https://archive.org/details/cyclopediaofpain02cham Volume 2 (Eakins to Kyhn)] :[https://archive.org/details/cyclopediaofpain03cham Volume 3 (Laar to Quost)] :[https://archive.org/details/cyclopediaofpain04cham Volume 4 (Raab to Zyl & supplement)].
*'''''[[English female artists]]''''' by [[Ellen Creathorne Clayton]] (London, [[Tinsley Brothers]], 1876): :[https://archive.org/details/englishfemalear00claygoog Volume 1] :[https://archive.org/details/englishfemalear02claygoog Volume 2].
==Art history==
===Engraving===
*'''''[https://books.google.com/books?id=4CsDAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Die deutschen Maler-Radierer des neunzehnten Jahrhunderts]''''' (German painters and engravers of the 19th century) by Andreas Andresen & Josef Eduard Wessely (Rudolph Weigel, 1866). German text. *'''''[https://archive.org/details/frenchengraverso00younuoft French engravers of the eighteenth century]''''' by A. Younger (London: Simpkin, Marshall, Hamilton Kent, 1913). *'''''[https://archive.org/details/frenchengraversd00dilkuoft French engravers and draughtsmen of the 18th century]''''' by E. F. S. Dilke (London: Bell, 1902). Illustrated. *'''''Les graveurs du dix-huitième siècle''''' (Engravers of the 18th century) by Roger Portalis & Henri Béraldi (Paris D. Morgand et C. Fatout, 1880). French text: :[https://archive.org/details/p1lesgraveursdud01portuoft Vol. 1, pt. 1 (Adam to Chevillet)] :[https://archive.org/details/p2lesgraveursdud01portuoft Vol. 1, pt. 2 (Chodowiecki to Dossier)] :[https://archive.org/details/p1lesgraveursdud02portuoft Vol. 2, pt. 1 (Les Drevet to Heinecken)] :[https://archive.org/details/p2lesgraveursdud02portuoft Vol. 2, pt. 2 (Helman to Marais)] :[https://archive.org/details/p1lesgraveursdud03portuoft Vol. 3, pt. 1 (Marcenay de Ghuy to Robert)] :[https://archive.org/details/p2lesgraveursdud03portuoft Vol. 3, pt. 1 (Roger to Zingg)].
*'''''[https://archive.org/details/oldengraversofen00salauoft The old engravers of England: in their relation to contemporary life and art,]''''' by Malcolm C. Salaman (London: Cassell, 1906).
===Painting===
*'''''Animal painters of England from the year 1650''''' by Sir [[Walter Gilbey]] (London: Vinton & Co., 1900): :[https://archive.org/details/animalpaintersof01gilb Volume 1 - Alken to Gooch] :[https://archive.org/details/animalpaintersof02gilb Volume 2 - Hancock to Wooton]
*'''''[https://books.google.com/books?id=AkQBAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Artistes Francais a l'étranger] (French artists abroad)''''' by Louis Dussieux (Paris: Gide & J. Baudry, 1856). French text. *'''''[https://archive.org/details/englishpainter00wilm English painters]''''' by H. J. Wilmot-Buxton (London : S. Low, Marston, Searle, & Rivington, 1883). Illustrated. *'''''[https://books.google.com/books?id=4CsDAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Die deutschen Maler-Radierer des neunzehnten Jahrhunderts]''''' (German painters and engravers of the 19th century) by Andreas Andresen & Josef Eduard Wessely (Rudolph Weigel, 1866). German text. *''[https://archive.org/details/frenchpainting00wile French Painting]'' by R. H. Wilenski (Boston, Hale, Cushman & Flint, inc., 1931). Comprehensive history of French art from earliest times. Illustrated in b/w *'''''[https://archive.org/details/frenchpaintingin00dimiuoft French painting in the sixteenth century] by Louis Dimitier (London Duckworth, 1904). *'''''[https://archive.org/details/historyamericanp00isha The history of American painting]''''' by [[Samuel Isham]] (New York: Macmillan, 1905). Illustrated. *'''''A history of painting''''' by Haldane Macfall (London, T. C. and E. C. Jack, 1911–1912). Illustrated: :[https://archive.org/details/historyofpaintin01macf Volume 1 - The renaissance in central Italy] :[https://archive.org/details/historyofpaintin02macf Volume 2 - The renaissance in Venice] :[https://archive.org/details/historyofpaintin03macf Volume 3 - Later Italians and genius of Spain] :[https://archive.org/details/historyofpaintin04macf Volume 4 - The renaissance in the north & the Flemish genius] :[https://archive.org/details/historyofpaintin05macf Volume 5 - The Dutch Genius] :[https://archive.org/details/historyofpaintin06macf Volume 6 - The French genius] :[https://archive.org/details/historyofpaintin07macf Volume 7 - The British genius] :[https://archive.org/details/historyofpaintin08macf Volume 8 - The modern genius]
*'''''The history of modern painting''''' by [[Richard Muther (art historian)|Richard Muther]] (London : J. M. Dent, 1907). Cals: ou, Le bonheur de peindre]'' by [[Arsène Alexandre|Alexandre, Arsène]] (Paris: G. Petit, 1900). French language. *[https://archive.org/details/constable00holmiala Constable]'' by C. J. Holmes (London: At the sign of the Unicorn, 1901). Landscape artist [[John Constable]]. Illustrated. *''[https://archive.org/details/fragonard00macfuoft Fragonard]'' by Haldane Macfall (London: T.C. & E.C. Jack, 1909). The life and work of [[Jean-Honoré Fragonard]] (1732–1806). *''[https://archive.org/details/bookoflovatclaud00macfuoft The book of Lovat, Claud Fraser]'' by Haldane Macfall (London: J.M. Dent, 1923). The life and work of [[Claud Lovat Fraser]] (1890–1921). *''[https://archive.org/details/aprilwilliampaynewate00longuoft William Payne, water-colour painter working 1776-1830]'' by Basil S. Long (London, Walker's Galleries, 1922). Illustrated. *''[https://archive.org/stream/vigelebrun00macfiala#page/n9/mode/2up Vigée-Le Brun]'' by Haldane Macfall (London: T.C. & E.C. Jack, 1909). The life and work of [[Élisabeth-Louise Vigée-Le Brun]] (1755–1842). *''[https://archive.org/details/whistler00macfiala Whistler]'' by Haldane Macfall (Boston: J. W. Luce, 1906). The life and work of [[James McNeill Whistler]]. *''[https://archive.org/details/araripe00macfuoft Araripe]'' by Alexei Bueno and others (Tiradentes: Oscar Araripe Foundation, 2011). The life and work of [[Oscar Araripe]] (1941–...).
===Collected biographies===
*''[https://archive.org/details/fouririshlandsca00bodkiala Four Irish landscape painters, George Barret, R. A., James A. O'Connor, Walter F. Osborne, R. H. A., Nathaniel Hone, R. H. A.]'' by Thomas Bodkin (London, T. F. Unwin ltd., 1920). B/w illustrations. *''[https://archive.org/details/germanmastersofa00dickuoft German masters of art]'' by H. A. Dickinson (New York, F.A. Stokes, 1914). *''[https://archive.org/details/greatenglishpain00cunn Great English painters ]'' by Alan Cunningham (Philadelphia : Jacobs, 1908). Illustrated. Included early artists up to Holbein, then, Hogarth, Wilson, Reynolds, Gainsborough and Blake. *''[https://archive.org/details/greatenglishpain00downuoft Great English painters ]'' by Francis Downman (London: W. Scott, 1886). Illustrated. Life and work of Hogarth, Reynolds, Gainsborough, Romney, Morland, Lawrence, Turner and Constable. *[https://archive.org/details/landscapefigurep00sher Landscape and figure painters of America] by F. F. Sherman (New York, privately printed, 1917). Biographies of [[Homer Dodge Martin]], [[Robert Loftin Newman]], [[Ralph Albert Blakelock]], [[Albert Pinkham Ryder]], Lilian M. Genth, [[Elliot Daingerfield]], [[Winslow Homer]], [[Alexander H. Wyant]], Dwight W. Tryon, J. Francis Murphy. Illustrated. *''[https://archive.org/details/cu31924031219714 The landscape and pastoral painters of Holland: Ruisdael, Hobbema, Cuijp, Potter]'' by Frank Cundall (New York, Scribner and Welford, 1891). *'''''The modern school of art''''' by Winifred Meynell (W. R. Howell, c. 1887). Biographies of 19th British century painters. Illustrated: :[https://archive.org/details/modernschoolofar01meynuoft Volume 1] :[https://archive.org/details/modernschoolofar02meynuoft Volume 2] :[https://archive.org/details/modernschoolofar03meynuoft Volume 3] :[https://archive.org/details/modernschoolofar04meynuoft Volume 4].
*''[https://archive.org/details/oldenglishmaster00cole Old English Masters]'' by Timothy Cole (New York: The Century Co., 1902). Artists from Hogarth to Landseer. Illustrated. *''[https://archive.org/details/thewyons00forriala The Wyons]'' by L. Forrer (London: Spink & Son, ltd., 1917). Talented family of designers, die-engravers and medallists. Illustrated in b/w.

Monkhouse]] (London, Seeley, 1897). Illustrated. *''[https://archive.org/details/earlyenglishwate00holmuoft Early English water-colour drawings by great masters]'' by Geoffrey Holme (Ed.) (The Studio, London, 1919).Illustrated. *''[https://archive.org/details/preraphaeeng00bateuoft The English pre-Raphaelite painters, their associates and successors]'' by Percy H. Bate (London: G. Bell & Sons, 1905). B/w illustrations. *'''''Famous Paintings''''': [https://archive.org/details/famouspaintings01chesuoft Volume 1], [https://archive.org/details/famouspaintings02chesuoft Volume 2] (Cassell, 1891). Many high-quality colour plates of paintings by artists of all nationalities. *''[https://archive.org/details/frenchpastellist00macfuoft The French pastellists of the eighteenth century] by Haldane Macfall (London: Macmillan, 1909). *''A history of the "Old water-colour" society, now the Royal society of painters in water colours'': [https://archive.org/details/historyofoldwate01rogeuoft Volume 1], [https://archive.org/details/historyofoldwate02rogeuoft Volume 2] by John Lewis Roget (London, Longmans, Green, and co., 1891). *''[https://archive.org/details/idealsofpainting00carrrich The ideals of painting]'' by [[J. Comyns Carr]] (New York, Macmillan, 1917). An Art history focusing on the ideals that inspired European artists throughout the ages. *''[https://archive.org/details/landscapepainti00gree Landscape painting and modern Dutch artists]'' by E. B. Greenshields (New York Baker and Taylor, 1906) *''[https://archive.org/details/modernbritishwat00balduoft Modern British water-colour drawings]'' by Alfred Lys Baldrey (London, The Studio, 1900). *''[https://archive.org/details/cu31924014891992 The Norwich School] by Geoffrey Holme (Ed.) (The Studio Ltd., 1920). About the artists of the English [[Norwich School (art movement)|Norwich School]]. *''[https://archive.org/details/shakespeareinpic00sala Shakespeare in pictorial art]'' by M. C. Salaman (The Studio Ltd., 1916). Illustrated.
==Art Journals==
* ''[https://archive.org/search.php?query=publisher%3A%22London+%3AbCassell+%26+Co.%22 The Magazine of Art]''. Illustrated art journal which ran from 1878–1904. * ''[https://archive.org/search.php?query=The%20Studio%20international%20AND%20mediatype%3Atexts&page=2 The Studio International - an illustrated magazine of fine and applied art]''. 1893–1980. Illustrated. Only volumes out of copyright are held. * ''[[The Wide World Magazine]]'' (Pub. by George Newnes). Travel and adventure magazine (1898–1965). Hundreds of b/w photos and drawings by top illustrators of the Victorian/ Edwardian period. * ''[[Art International]]''

Jahrhunderts'' (Bremen: Ed. Lumière, 2007), {{ISBN|3-934686-28-1}}. * 17th-18th Century Burney Collection Newspapers Title List [http://access.gale.com/gdc/documents/Burney%20Collection%20Title%20List.pdf] == Notes == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * Eighteenth Century Journals. A Portal to Newspapers and Periodicals c.1685–1815. [restricted access] * Retrospektive Digitalisierung wissenschaftlicher Rezensionsorgane und Literaturzeitschriften des 18. und 19. Jahrhunderts aus dem deutschen Sprachraum. [[File:Bobines de Filme na Cinemateca Portuguesa..png|thumb|right|Film reels in the [[Cinemateca Portuguesa]].]] This is a '''list of [[film archives]] and [[cinematheque]]s'''. Film archives collect, restore, investigate and conserve audiovisual content like films, documentaries, television programs and newsreel footage. Often, every country has its own film archive to preserve the national audiovisual heritage. The [[International Federation of Film Archives]] comprises more than 150 institutions in over 77 countries and the [[Association of European Film Archives and Cinematheques]] is an affiliation of 44 European national and regional film archives founded in 1991.
{{TOC right}}
==International== European Film Gateway provides quick and easy access to hundreds of thousands of film historical documents as preserved in European film archives and cinémathèques: photos, posters, programmes, periodicals, censorship documents, rare feature and documentary films, newsreels and other materials. It is still a beta version and provides access to about 30 film archives.

{{Other uses}} {{Distinguish|Monograph|Nomogram}} [[File:VOC stone.jpg|thumb|180px|Monogram logo of the [[Dutch East India Company]] ("[[Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie]]", or "VOC" in Dutch), formerly above the entrance to the [[Castle of Good Hope]] in South Africa. The VOC's well-designed monogram logo was possibly in fact the first globally recognized [[corporate logo]].<ref>[[Timothy Brook|Brook, Timothy]]: ''[[Vermeer's Hat|Vermeer's Hat: The Seventeenth Century and the Dawn of the Global World]]''. (New York: Bloomsbury Press, 2008), p. 16</ref>]] [[File:Louis Vuitton logo and wordmark.svg|thumb|100px|[[Louis Vuitton]]'s monogram logo]] [[File:Chanel logo interlocking cs.svg|thumb|100px|[[Coco Chanel]]'s logo]] A '''monogram''' is a [[motif (art)|motif]] made by overlapping or combining two or more letters or other [[grapheme]]s to form one [[symbol]]. Monograms are often made by combining the initials of an individual or a company, used as recognizable symbols or [[logo]]s. A series of uncombined initials is properly referred to as a cypher (e.g. a [[royal cypher]]) and is not a monogram.<ref>The [[Shorter Oxford English Dictionary]] (Fifth edition; 2002) defines it as a "device composed of two or more letters... interwoven together." Volume 1, p. 1820.</ref>
==History== [[File:Albrecht Dürer Monogramm.svg|thumb|left|100px|The "AD" monogram that [[Albrecht Dürer]] used as a signature]] Monograms first appeared on coins, as early as 350BC. The earliest known examples are of the names of Greek cities which issued the coins, often the first two letters of the city's name. For example, the monogram of [[Achaea (ancient region)|Achaea]] consisted of the letters [[alpha]] (Α) and [[chi (letter)|chi]] (Χ) joined together.<ref>Henry Noel Humphreys, ''The Coin Collector's Manual, Or Guide to Numismatic Student in the Formation of a Cabinet of Coins'' (Bibliolife, 2008), 226.</ref>
Monograms have been used as signatures by artists and [[Artisan|craftsmen]] on paintings, sculptures and pieces of furniture, especially when [[guilds]] enforced measures against unauthorized participation in the trade. A famous example of a monogram serving as an artist's signature is the "AD" used by [[Albrecht Dürer]]. {{Clear}}
==Christograms== {{Main|Christogram}} [[File:Sarcophage de Drausin 03 chrisme.jpg|thumb|right|100px|The [[Chi-Rho]], a monogram of the first two letters of the Greek word for [[Christ]]]]
Over the centuries, monograms of the name of [[Jesus]] [[Christ]] have been used as [[Christian symbolism|Christian symbols]]. The [[IX monogram]] consists of the initial Greek letters of the name "Jesus Christ," "I" for Ιησούς, ([[Jesus]] in Greek) and "X" for Χριστος ([[Christ]] in Greek). The "IHS" Christogram, denoting the first three letters of the Greek name of Jesus, is usually written as a cypher, but sometimes as a monogram. Perhaps the most significant [[Christogram]] is the [[Chi Rho]], formed from the first two letters of Χριστος. {{Clear}}
==Royal monograms== [[File:Royal Monogram of King Boris III of Bulgaria.svg|thumb|left|100px|Royal Monogram of [[Kingdom of Bulgaria|Bulgarian]] king [[Boris III of Bulgaria|Boris III]]]]
[[File:Signum manus of Charlemagne.svg|thumb|upright|Cross-signature of [[Charlemagne]] ]] [[Signum manus]] (sometimes also known as ''Chrismon'') refers to the medieval practice, current from the [[Merovingian period]] until the 14th century in the [[Frankish Empire]] and its successors, of signing a document or charter with a special type of monogram or royal cypher.
[[File:Christian VII AR Speciedaler 79001450.jpg|thumb|right|Speciedaler of [[Denmark]], bearing the double C7 monogram of [[Christian VII of Denmark|Christian VII]]]] Monograms of the names of [[monarch]]s are used as part of the insignia of public organizations in kingdoms, such as on police badges. This indicates a connection to the ruler. However, the [[royal cypher]], so familiar on [[pillar box]]es, is not technically a monogram, since the letters are not combined.
Royal monograms often appear on coins, frequently surmounted by a crown. Countries that have employed this device in the past include [[Bulgaria]], [[Great Britain]], [[Russia]], [[Sweden]] and many [[List of historic states of Germany|German states]]. Today, several [[Danish krone|Danish coins]] carry the monogram of [[Margrethe II of Denmark|Margrethe II]], while the current Norwegian 1 [[Norwegian krone|Krone coin]] has the "H5" monogram of [[Harald V of Norway|Harald V]] on the [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]].<ref>[http://www.norges-bank.no/templates/article____12369.aspx Coins] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110203082931/http://www.norges-bank.no/templates/article____12369.aspx |date=2011-02-03 }}, at the [[Norges Bank]] website.</ref> The only countries using the [[Euro]] to have a royal monogram as their [[Identifying marks on euro coins|national identifying mark]] are [[Belgian euro coins|Belgium]] and [[Monegasque euro coins|Monaco]].<ref>A [[€2 commemorative coins|commemorative €2 coin]] from [[Luxembourgish euro coins|Luxembourg]] carried the monogram of [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Grand Duke Henri]].</ref> In Thailand, royal monograms appear on the individual flag for each major royal family member. {{Clear}}
==Individual monograms== [[File:Dress shirt monogram locations.svg|thumb|Dress shirt monogram locations]]
An individual's monogram is often a very fancy piece of art used for stationery, for adorning luggage, for embroidery on clothing, and so forth. These monograms may have two or three letters.
A basic 3-letter monogram has the initial of the individual's last name (surname) set larger, or with some special treatment in the center, while the first name initial appears to the left of it and the middle name initial appears to the right of it. There is a difference in how this is written for men and women. For example, if the individual's name is Mary Ann Jones, and Jones is the surname, then the arrangement of letters would be thus: '''M<big>J</big>A''', with the surname initial set larger in the center, the '''M''' for Mary to the left and the '''A''' for Ann to the right.<ref name="3LM">Jeanine Twigg, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=j6e847_n3MUC&pg=PA43 Embroidery Machine Essentials: How to Stabilize, Hoop and Stitch Decorative Designs]'', KP Craft, 2001, {{ISBN|0-87341-999-5}}, p. 43.</ref> Traditionally, individual monograms for men<ref>https://www.simplystamps.com/blog/2016/06/30/monogram-guide-how-to/</ref> are based on the order of the name. The name Kyle George Martin would be written ('''KGM''').
Married or engaged couples may use two-letter monograms of their entwined initials, for example on [[wedding invitations]]. Married couples may also create three-letter monograms incorporating the initial of their shared surname. For example, the monogram '''M<big>J</big>A''' might be used for Michael and Alice Jones.<ref name="3LM"/> However, monogramming etiquette for the married couple varies according to the item being monogrammed. Linens, for example, typically list the woman's given initial first, followed by the couple's shared surname initial and then the man's given initial ('''A<big>J</big>M''').<ref name="What is a Monogram">{{Cite web|title = What is a Monogram?|url = http://www.homewetbar.com/blog/what-is-monogram/|accessdate = 2015-07-02}}</ref>
Monograms can often be found on custom dress shirts where they can be located in a number of different positions.
Some personal monograms have become famous symbols in their own right and instantly recognizable to many, such as [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s monogram. {{Clear}}
==Other monograms== [[File:UT&T text logo.svg|thumb|110px|left|The [[University of Texas at Austin|UT]] monogram]]
{{see also|Logo}} Some companies and organizations adopt a monogram for a logo, usually with the letters of their [[acronym]]. For example, as well as having an official [[Seal (emblem)|seal]], and the [[Texas Longhorns]] logo, the [[University of Texas at Austin]] uses a "UT" monogram (in the same color as the Longhorns logo, [[burnt orange]]). The [[New York Yankees]] baseball team also uses a monogram on their [[ball cap]] insignia. <!-- (I'm commenting out this bit because it makes no sense. If you can explain, please do. Thanks!) and French [[soccer]] team [[Olympique de Marseille]] use a monogram taken from in funder. --> The [[Consolidated Edison]] logo, with a rounded "E" nested inside a "C," has been described as a "classic emblem."<ref>[[Bloomberg BusinessWeek|BusinessWeek]] online, [http://www.businessweek.com/innovate/content/aug2005/id20050811_494381.htm Con Ed: The Power of a Logo], 11 August 2005.</ref>
Many fashion companies have a monogram for a logo, including [[Louis Vuitton]] and [[Fendi]]. The connected "CC" company logo, created by [[Coco Chanel]], is one of the most recognizable monograms internationally.<ref name="What is a Monogram"/>
Athletes have also been known to brand merchandise with their monogram logo; notably [[Tiger Woods]] and [[Roger Federer]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Brubach|first1=Holly|title=The Main Characters of Tennis, and Style|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/31/sports/tennis/31logo.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=21 August 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=August 29, 2009}}</ref> {{Clear}}
== Resistance symbols in wartime == [[File:Kotwica symbol.svg|thumb|60px|''Polska Walcząca'' - "Fighting Poland"]]
A notable example of a royal monogram is the [[H7 (monogram)|H7]] monogram of King [[Haakon VII of Norway]]. While in exile during [[World War II]], Haakon VII spearheaded the Norwegian resistance to the [[Occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany|German occupation]], and H7 became a symbol used by the Norwegian populace to mark solidarity and loyalty to the King, and adherence to the [[Norwegian resistance movement]]. The act of drawing or creating a H7 symbol in German-occupied Norway was punishable by imprisonment.<ref>{{cite news|title=Meldinger fra Norge|last=Hjeltnes|first=Guri|authorlink=Guri Hjeltnes|date=7 April 2008|work=VG|pages=2|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
Similarly, during [[World War II]] in Poland, the "PW" monogram was used as a resistance symbol, known as ''The Anchor'', or [[Kotwica]] due to its characteristic shape. Its meaning varied, as the initials were useful for many different slogans, such as ''Poland Fights'', ''Warsaw Uprising'', ''Polish Army'' and others. Like the Norwegian example above, its use was punished by the Nazi occupation authorities.
==Japanese== {{main|Japanese rebus monogram}} A Japanese rebus monogram is a monogram in a particular style, which spells a name via a [[rebus]], as a form of [[Japanese wordplay]] or [[visual pun]]. Today they are most often seen in corporate logos or product logos.
==Gallery== <gallery widths="154px" heights="200px" perrow="5" caption="Monograms selection"> File:Mark Twain-The American Claimant-1896-Logo on Cover.jpg|Logo on cover of 1896 edition of ''[[:en:The American Claimant|The American Claimant]]'' by [[Mark Twain]] File:Mongr Serv 01.jpg|[[Napkin]] with embroidered monogram File:Kronene i Håvet.JPG|[[Norway|Norwegian]] royal monograms carved in a mountainside to mark royal visits to [[Kongsberg]] since 1623 File:IMG 4341 - Milano - Galleria Vittorio Emanuele - Le 4 capitali Roma - Foto Giovanni Dall'Orto 20-jan 2007.jpg|''[[SPQR]]'', detail from the mosaic floor in the [[Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II]] File:Monogram of Peter II.svg|Monogram of [[Pedro II of Brazil|Pedro II]], [[List of monarchs of Brazil|Emperor of Brazil]] File:Royal_Monogram_of_King_Rama_X.svg|Royal monogram of King [[Maha Vajiralongkorn]] of Thailand </gallery>
==See also== *[[Signum manus]] *[[Interrobang]] *[[Kaō]] *[[Typographic ligature|Ligature]] *[[Varsity letter]] *[[Nicolas Verrien]], 17th-century French monogram designer *[[Sigil (magic)]]
==References== {{Commons category|Monograms}} <references/>
{{Authority control}} {{Personal names}} [[Category:Monograms]]

revision.text:
{{infobox Museum |name=Museum of Serbs of Croatia
''Muzej Srba u Hrvatskoj''
Музеј Срба у Хрватској |image= Hrvatski povijesni muzej.jpg | caption = in 1963 ''Museum of Serbs of Croatia'' became part of ''Museum of Croatian History'' | map_type = Croatia | map_caption = | map_alt = |coordinates = {{coord|45.8|16.07|display=inline}} |established=1946 |dissolved=1963 |location=[[Zagreb]], [[Socialist Republic of Croatia]] |visitors= |director= |publictransit = |website= }} '''Museum of Serbs of Croatia''' ({{lang-hr|Muzej Srba u Hrvatskoj}}, {{lang-sr-Cyrl|Музеј Срба у Хрватској}}) was a public museum in [[Zagreb]], which was specialized in history of [[Serbs of Croatia]]. Museum existed from 1946 till 1963 when it became part of [[Croatian History Museum]]. Today, part of the material is kept in Museum of [[Metropolitanate of Zagreb and Ljubljana]],{{cite journal | language = Serbo-Croatian |title = Otvoren Muzej Srpske pravoslavne crkve eparhije zagrebačko-ljubljanske | first = Anica | last = Vlašić-Anić | journal = Slovo: časopis Staroslavenskog instituta | volume = | number = 35 | month = | year = 1985 | location = Zagreb | url = http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=22358 | accessdate = 2013-04-29}} part in [[Prosvjeta]],{{cite web|url=http://snv.hr/sto-radimo/kultura/arhiviranje|title= Arhivske jedinice|format= |date= |accessdate=2015-09-04}} some in Museum of Croatian History and part of them were destroyed in mining of Museum of Metropolitanate of Zagreb and Ljubljana on 11 April 1992 during [[War in Croatia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mitropolija-zagrebacka.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=34&lang=sr|title= Popis imovine Crkvene opštine u Zagrebu|format= |date= |accessdate=2013-04-29}} In 2009, on 65 anniversary of [[Prosvjeta]], organization has launched an initiative for restoration of museum work.{{cite web|url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Kultura/Kulturni-svetionik-Srba-u-Hrvatskoj.sr.html|title= Културни светионик Срба у Хрватској|date= 2009-07-28|accessdate=2013-04-29}} ==History== During the [[World War II]] group of Croatian museum professionals collected some number of artifacts from churches and monasteries of [[Serbian Orthodox Church]] in [[Independent State of Croatia]] that escaped [[Ustaše]] destruction, and stored them in [[Museum of Arts and Crafts, Zagreb|Museum of Arts and Crafts]].{{cite journal | language = Serbo-Croatian |title = Znanstvene ustanove-Muzej Srba u Hrvatskoj | first = Fedor | last = Moačin | journal = Historijski zbornik | volume = 1 | number = 1-4 | month = | year = 1948 | location = Zagreb | url = http://www.historiografija.hr/hz/1948/HZ_1_16_MOACANIN.pdf | accessdate = 2013-04-29}} After the end of war in 1946, on initiative of [[Main Board of Serbs in Croatia]] and [[Prosvjeta]], from material from these collection and added non-religious materials, was established Museum of Serbs of Croatia as part of Museum of Arts and Crafts. In early in 1948 it became part of Museum of Croatian History. Since 1963 museum as division was annexed to Museum of Croatian History and after few years that division were dissolved.{{cite web|url=http://www.skdprosvjeta.com/news.php?id=651|title= Branislav Ćelap za uzor drugima-Prosvjeta|format= |date= |accessdate=2013-04-29}} ==Sections== The museum collection was divided into five halls: *1.Since settling in Croatia till Great Serb Migrations in 1690 *2.Art and craft works of the 18th century *3.Church, army and people in the 18th century *4.Citizenry and Enlightenment at the turn of the 18th into the 19th century *5.Exhibition of paintings by Serbian painters from Croatia ==See also== * [[List of museums in Croatia]] * [[Serbs of Croatia]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Serbian minority institutions and organizations in Croatia}} [[Category:Defunct museums]] [[Category:History of the Serbs of Croatia]] [[Category:Museums in Zagreb]] [[Category:Museums established in 1946]] [[Category:1946 establishments in Yugoslavia]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox Korean name |hangul=난중일기 |hanja=亂中日記 |rr=Nanjung(-)ilgi |mr=Nanjung ilgi }} '''''Nanjung Ilgi''''' or '''''War Diary of Yi Sun-sin''''' is the personal diary of [[Admiral]] [[Yi Sun-sin]] ([[Hangul]]: 이순신, [[Hanja]]: 李舜臣), a Korean naval commander who lived during the [[Joseon Dynasty]]. It was written between January 1, 1592 and November 17, 1598, a first person narrative of the admiral's perspective on the [[Japanese invasions of Korea (1592-1598)|Japanese invasions of Korea in the late 16th century]].
It is the 76th [[National treasures of Korea|national treasure of Korea]] and listed in [[UNESCO]]'s [[Memory of the World]] registry.
==Contents==
The original ''Nanjung Ilgi'' consists of 205 folio pages divided into 7 volumes.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ha|first1=Tae-hung|title=Nanjung Ilgi: War Diary of Admiral Yi Sun-sin|date=1977|publisher=Yonsei University Press|location=Seoul, South Korea|isbn=8971410183|page=xi}}</ref> Entries detail the admiral's daily life in a military camp, his strategies, his naval campaigns, the names and dispositions of various military officers and civil officials with whom Admiral Yi interacted, geographic and atmospheric details, and his personal observations and commentary on the events and circumstances of his military command. These entries are not continuous: there are breaks in the narrative throughout the diary, representative of periods of time in which Admiral Yi was unable to maintain daily entries.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ha|first1=Tae-hung|title=Nanjung Ilgi: War Diary of Admiral Yi Sun-sin|date=1977|publisher=Yonsei University Press|location=Seoul, South Korea|isbn=8971410183|pages=23–24}}</ref> There is also some overlap between Volumes 5 and 6, where Admiral Yi apparently later revised earlier entries.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ha|first1=Tae-hung|title=Nanjung Ilgi: War Diary of Admiral Yi Sun-sin|date=1977|publisher=Yonsei University Press|location=Seoul, South Korea|isbn=8971410183|page=xi}}</ref>
===Volume 1=== Volume 1 consists of 27 folio pages, covering the entries from the 1st of 5th moon 1592 to the 22nd of 3rd moon 1593.
===Volume 2=== Volume 2 consists of 30 folio pages, covering the entries from the 1st day of 5th moon 1593 to the 15th day of 9th moon 1593.
===Volume 3=== Volume 2 consists of 50 folio pages, covering the entries from the 1st day of 1st moon 1594 to the 28th day of 11th moon 1594.
===Volume 4=== Volume 4 consists of 41 folio pages, covering the entries from the 1st day of 1st moon 1596 to the 11th day of 10th moon 1596.
===Volume 5=== Volume 5 consists of 27 folio pages, covering the entries from the 1st day of 4th moon 1597 to the 8th day of 10th moon 1597.
===Volume 6=== Volume 6 consists of 20 folio pages, covering the entries from the 4th day of 8th moon 1597 to the 4th day of 1st moon 1598.
===Volume 7=== Volume 7 consists of 8 folio pages, covering the entries from the 15th day of 9th moon 1598 to the 7th day of 10th moon 1598.
== References == {{reflist}}
== Sources == *{{cite book|author=Ha, Tae-hung|title=Nanjung Ilgi: War Diary of Admiral Yi Sun-sin|publisher=Yonsei University Press|isbn=8971410183|year=1977}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060505231122/http://www.koreanhero.net/en/WarDiary.htm ''The War Diary of Yi Sun-sin''] *{{Ko icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20071027024715/http://www.ocp.go.kr:9000/n_dasencgi/full.cgi?v_db=1&v_doc_no=00000076 이충무공 난중일기 부서간첩 임진장초] - 문화재청
{{Joseon}}
[[Category:Joseon Dynasty works]] [[Category:Military books]] [[Category:Yi Sun-sin]] [[Category:1590s books]] [[Category:Korean non-fiction books]] [[Category:National Treasures of South Korea]] [[Category:Memory of the World Register]]
